I'm disappointed that this book wasn't what I thought it would be. I hoped for more technical information and techniques, and less guru style fluff.If you are struggling to accept your hair, it's a bit Chicken-Soup for the Soul, with the Curly Confessions, and the 12 Steps Promise (to not abuse your hair anymore) and the hair horoscopes.I was personally hoping for more balanced insight on porous/texture aspects of hair rather than main focus on the shape of each curl.I will say I found the hairstyles nice to include, as well as the recipes for protein masks and diy gel spray, and tips for cutting your own hair, but I was disappointed that none of the videos were supported by my device.Overall, not for me, and there is as much if not more info in blogs that don't cost $10.

It is not possible to give advice about care for every type of curly hair, since individuals' hair varies widely.  However, this book attempts to classify several different types of curls and gives some general principles that the reader can apply, through trial and error, to find out what works best for her (or his) own curly head.If not properly cared for, much curly hair does not appear curly but just frizzy, poufy, flyaway, and out of control. If this describes your hair, it's possible that you have curls and don't know it.  Much of the hair care advice that we get for straight hair is actually the opposite of what should be done for curly hair, so if you start the Curly Girl regimen, you might be surprised to find that you actually do have natural curls.But that's only half the book.  The other half is a sort of manifesto.  Apparently, very many people with curly hair have had traumatic experiences where they did not know how to care for their hair nor did anyone else (such as their mothers and hairdressers).  Some were told their hair was unruly, wrong, "I can't do anything with it," or "unprofessional."  Curly hair is treated as a problem to be solved.  There is a strong ideological component to this book, to help naturally curly folks get over the mental block caused by this societal attitude.  Sprinkled throughout the book are testimonies by men and women about how they came to accept their curls. There is even a tongue-in-cheek "12 Steps" at the back (some of them somewhat contrived) to lead the reader accept his or her curly hair and commit to care for it as such.There are also numerous "curl" puns sprinkled throughout.  The tone is light, like a woman's magazine article extended to book length.I thought the curly-as-identity stuff was a little heavy-handed.  One of the women, in her testimony, even refers to it as the "curly girl religion" (unless that was a typo for regimen), and that's not too far off the mark.  I am naturally curly, but I don't think of myself as belonging to a victim class.  Still, the book has good information about hair care, and I can imagine that some people might have a very hard time giving up straightening their hair, and would need all the identity stuff as an encouragement.  The strong ideological tone grew out of the author's own experience of starting out hating, and then learning to love, her hair.According to the book, an estimated 65% of women have hair that has some amount of natural curl to it (varying from waves to "fractal" curls).  I can only imagine that very many of them must be straightening theirs.  Although I don't by any means think of straight-haired folks as oppressors nor do I want anyone with straight hair to feel inferior either, I do hope that an increasing number of curly-haired women decide to go natural, so that curly hair can become as normal, professional, and serious a look as straight.

I have always had what others refer to as 'The Bush' as in this wad of curly frizz on my head. Now my hairs mellowed out into what looks like long beach curls. Or so I've been told. Either way I used a few techniques from this book, like how to cut my hair without fraying it. Using oils while it's drying so that there's no frizz. And realizing that I don't need to use shampoo, which is still scary to me.What I really like about the book is that it doesn't read like a manual. It reads like someone with experience is telling you how to take car of your hair. It has relate able stories from fellow curly girls, about their curls. Hair style ideas, and even a Curly Girl Horoscope. My physical copy came with a DVD too, for those that need visuals when cutting their own hair or styling it.On the downside, my hairdresser thinks I'm a snob now. Because I want my hair cut dry, and I show her exactly where to cut. This book gave me too much confidence/authority over my hair. Read at your own risk.

I have hair like Natasha Lyonne, 2c/3a curls. I can see how a lot of these tips work for other people, especially very curly hair. I have frizzy, upon frizzy, upon frizzy, wavy/swavy sometimes curly hair with seborrheic dermatitis/psoriasis (weird oily/dry scalp).Edit: I'm changing my review from a 4 to a 5. To those who feel discouraged, there is hope! Since the first time I reviewed the book I cut about 10 inches of my hair off. It rests at my shoulders now, and is a lot easier to experiment with since there is so much less of it. As of May 2015, no heating tools have touched my head, and it has worked out very nicely! It is almost the end of the summer and I have not cursed the humidity once.I'm still using a sulfate-free shampoo (AG Fast Food Shampoo), and I switch between Tresemme Un(done) conditioner (silicone and glycerin free) and Yes to Carrots conditioner. I use a leave-in conditioner and Ouidad Climate Control Gel (alcohol free). Navigating the curly hair products has been a lot easier after reading this book, and I think its a good resource for anyone who wants better curls.

It's hard to believe after a lifetime of frustration I've actually found a system that's not only helped me love my curly hair, I absolutely no longer covet straight hair.  I now feel like the one who is to be envied!  Every (no exaggeration) single time I go out I now get compliments on my hair...what a wonderful feeling.  And those compliments come not only from those who've known me forever; the most gratifying compliments come from total strangers.  Wow.When you try this method, all I can say is absorb the advice and follow it--doing so has indeed changed the way I feel about myself.  It has SO boosted my self-confidence.  I have been going 'natural' for years and had terrible frustrations over the omnipresent frizz and dried-out hair.  No longer--even on rainy, humid days.I have my hair colored--soon after initially getting it colored I started having a terrible time with extreme dryness.  My hairdresser insisted the coloring had nothing to do with it, but I know better now.  This book confirmed my suspicions, but the dryness is in the past now, after using the types of products suggested, and understanding more about my hair.  The book does not push a particular brand of products but explains ingredients to avoid.  Having said that, I have to admit I now use nothing but the product line developed by the author--DevaCurl.  Some products of the line I like better than others, and they are not inexpensive, but they work--along with following what the book tells you to do.  I started out trying one of their 'kits', which included smaller (8 oz) bottles of cleanser, conditioner and a small microfiber towel because it was a less expensive way to try the products...at least that way I could see if they worked without going overboard.  They worked.  I also have tried lots of additional DevaCurl products by buying when they offer specials--where your purchase also gets you small containers of other DevaCurl products.  As I stated earlier, some I like better than others, but that you must determine for yourself.  Rather than buying a large microfiber towel, I use a large cotton man's t-shirt, as suggested in the book, and that works great.  The book also provides recipes so you can make your own products--I haven't tried that, but I certainly love the DevaCurl stuff, so I just buy those.The lady who wrote this book has become a hero (or heroine) to thousands, and rightfully so.  She is certainly one of mine.  I even went to the website and found an area that shows you where to find hairdressers who have been trained in using her method (which includes dry-cutting your hair--makes such perfect sense--read the book--when hair is cut wet you have no idea how each curl is going to dry).  I live in a rural mountain area and now drive 75 miles each way to get my hair cut/colored by someone who understands and gives a s**t about how to deal with curly hair.  Fortunately, I only have to go every 10-12 weeks...part of the benefit of a proper cut, and the curl helps hide the roots.Didn't mean to write so much, but the method this book describes should be mandatory for every hairdresser and every curly-haired person out there.  I don't think you can go wrong if you use this system.  I'd almost pay people to read this book.

I found some great advice for my wavy hair. I'm a wash and go girl, and prefer naturals, so I appreciate the perspective that encouraging healthy hair with good, natural ingredients and no fuss is the best way to shine. The guide helps you identify what your hair type is (wavy, curly, coily etc.) then gives a care and style program. It requires spending a little money and going outside the normal drugstore aisle to find good products, but there are excellent products out there that won't break the bank. Already got compliments on my hair after trying some of the practical advice.

This is a great book! I had the privilege and honor to meet Lorraine at her book signing in my hometown! I posted the picture below! What a lovely and energetic woman! Lorraine really goes into great detail and care to teach you how to take care of your hair! Every little tip helps my hair feel better, look better and gives me so much confidence! I was raised to straighten my hair, so when I learned how to let it go natural I was amazed! It's so much easier to take care of and every hair day is a good one! I am no longer scared of raining day frizz! What a relief! It's only been a week, but I am dedicated to loving my hair the way it is intended to be. Also check out Lorraine Massey's "Silver Hair" as she teaches you how to grow out your color and say goodbye to dye!

At nearly 60 I am a beginner with my curly hair. I've always kept it very short to deal with unmanageable curl (I thought) and to avoid heat and chemicals. This is a new life adventure for me and I am having much fun and success with these methods. I might explore Devacurl products but any no sulphate, parade, silicone or alcohol products may work for you as they do for me using these methods.The DVDs work great on iPad plus you get the full color photos.

It's a bit cutesy and juvenile with all the plays on words, etc. Some of the curl styles are also a bit too similar to be considered distinct, but I really appreciated the washing and drying tips (which REALLY do work to maximize curls and avoid frizz), plus the lack of YOU MUST BUY THESE DEVA PRODUCTS upsell that so many other style guides push. The recipes are also a nice add, though I haven't tried them yet. It was a fun read and having been to a Deva-certified stylist a few times now, I'm sold on the method. My hair's never looked better and been so easy to style, even when I travel overseas. I actually do use 3 of the Deva products (and happily so). Thanks Lorraine!

First off, I give the seller 5 stars for quick delivery and item being in flawless condition. However, that doesn't apply to the book. I am trying to go back to my curly hair and everyone on Youtube and well...the whole internet practically highly recommend this book. I do appreciate the tips given and without reading it, I would have thought the curly lifestyle was going to be too complicated. So that helped simplify things in that instance but the book still lacked something. If I hadn't come across curl friends talking about hair porosity, I would've never known about it, especially there being no mention about it anywhere that I found in this book. To me, porosity is a huge importance learning about your hair, the products to use and application. The author only covers how to take care of your curls by curl shapes, not porosity and someone with low porosity, I was in a constant battle with products and application. I am NOT saying that this book is absolutely useless, just wish there was less testimonials and more information on products and porosity...more science, I guess.  I recommend going to the library and checking out the book before buying it, that way you can be sure if it's something you can't live without going back to curls.

I'm disappointed that this book wasn't what I thought it would be. I hoped for more technical information and techniques, and less guru style fluff.If you are struggling to accept your hair, it's a bit Chicken-Soup for the Soul, with the Curly Confessions, and the 12 Steps Promise (to not abuse your hair anymore) and the hair horoscopes.I was personally hoping for more balanced insight on porous/texture aspects of hair rather than main focus on the shape of each curl.I will say I found the hairstyles nice to include, as well as the recipes for protein masks and diy gel spray, and tips for cutting your own hair, but I was disappointed that none of the videos were supported by my device.Overall, not for me, and there is as much if not more info in blogs that don't cost $10.

It is not possible to give advice about care for every type of curly hair, since individuals' hair varies widely.  However, this book attempts to classify several different types of curls and gives some general principles that the reader can apply, through trial and error, to find out what works best for her (or his) own curly head.If not properly cared for, much curly hair does not appear curly but just frizzy, poufy, flyaway, and out of control. If this describes your hair, it's possible that you have curls and don't know it.  Much of the hair care advice that we get for straight hair is actually the opposite of what should be done for curly hair, so if you start the Curly Girl regimen, you might be surprised to find that you actually do have natural curls.But that's only half the book.  The other half is a sort of manifesto.  Apparently, very many people with curly hair have had traumatic experiences where they did not know how to care for their hair nor did anyone else (such as their mothers and hairdressers).  Some were told their hair was unruly, wrong, "I can't do anything with it," or "unprofessional."  Curly hair is treated as a problem to be solved.  There is a strong ideological component to this book, to help naturally curly folks get over the mental block caused by this societal attitude.  Sprinkled throughout the book are testimonies by men and women about how they came to accept their curls. There is even a tongue-in-cheek "12 Steps" at the back (some of them somewhat contrived) to lead the reader accept his or her curly hair and commit to care for it as such.There are also numerous "curl" puns sprinkled throughout.  The tone is light, like a woman's magazine article extended to book length.I thought the curly-as-identity stuff was a little heavy-handed.  One of the women, in her testimony, even refers to it as the "curly girl religion" (unless that was a typo for regimen), and that's not too far off the mark.  I am naturally curly, but I don't think of myself as belonging to a victim class.  Still, the book has good information about hair care, and I can imagine that some people might have a very hard time giving up straightening their hair, and would need all the identity stuff as an encouragement.  The strong ideological tone grew out of the author's own experience of starting out hating, and then learning to love, her hair.According to the book, an estimated 65% of women have hair that has some amount of natural curl to it (varying from waves to "fractal" curls).  I can only imagine that very many of them must be straightening theirs.  Although I don't by any means think of straight-haired folks as oppressors nor do I want anyone with straight hair to feel inferior either, I do hope that an increasing number of curly-haired women decide to go natural, so that curly hair can become as normal, professional, and serious a look as straight.

I have always had what others refer to as 'The Bush' as in this wad of curly frizz on my head. Now my hairs mellowed out into what looks like long beach curls. Or so I've been told. Either way I used a few techniques from this book, like how to cut my hair without fraying it. Using oils while it's drying so that there's no frizz. And realizing that I don't need to use shampoo, which is still scary to me.What I really like about the book is that it doesn't read like a manual. It reads like someone with experience is telling you how to take car of your hair. It has relate able stories from fellow curly girls, about their curls. Hair style ideas, and even a Curly Girl Horoscope. My physical copy came with a DVD too, for those that need visuals when cutting their own hair or styling it.On the downside, my hairdresser thinks I'm a snob now. Because I want my hair cut dry, and I show her exactly where to cut. This book gave me too much confidence/authority over my hair. Read at your own risk.

I have hair like Natasha Lyonne, 2c/3a curls. I can see how a lot of these tips work for other people, especially very curly hair. I have frizzy, upon frizzy, upon frizzy, wavy/swavy sometimes curly hair with seborrheic dermatitis/psoriasis (weird oily/dry scalp).Edit: I'm changing my review from a 4 to a 5. To those who feel discouraged, there is hope! Since the first time I reviewed the book I cut about 10 inches of my hair off. It rests at my shoulders now, and is a lot easier to experiment with since there is so much less of it. As of May 2015, no heating tools have touched my head, and it has worked out very nicely! It is almost the end of the summer and I have not cursed the humidity once.I'm still using a sulfate-free shampoo (AG Fast Food Shampoo), and I switch between Tresemme Un(done) conditioner (silicone and glycerin free) and Yes to Carrots conditioner. I use a leave-in conditioner and Ouidad Climate Control Gel (alcohol free). Navigating the curly hair products has been a lot easier after reading this book, and I think its a good resource for anyone who wants better curls.

I now feel like the one who is to be envied!  Every (no exaggeration) single time I go out I now get compliments on my hair...what a wonderful feeling.  And those compliments come not only from those who've known me forever; the most gratifying compliments come from total strangers. After having very straight hair my entire life for the last few years it has been a triangular fuzz ball no matter who cut and styled it. I tried different hair professionals. When I saw this book it all clicked! I went to beauty school back in the day before my hair turned grey. Just by looking at the front of the book I new I had wavy/curly hair and had been destroying it by treating it as straight hair. It is a easy read and informative book. Straight and wavycurly hair are totally different worlds. Plenty on you tube about the 'curly girl method CGM' for more help. However all that information on you tube is confusing since every curl is different. The book was most helpful in narrowing down what info was for my hair type. 2abc and on a good day I have a couple 3a curls. All you need to know if you are a new curly. There are a lot of people who have fuzzy hair who don't know that frizzy fuzz is actually curlywavy hair that needs to be cared for properly so you can enjoy your natural hair.

This is definitely a must have book for anyone who has curly hair that has never really known how to properly take care of it. I grew up with a mother who has pin straight hair, an older sister with pin straight hair, and a father and little sister who has curly hair. You'd think since the curlies are dominant in the family that we would all know how to take care of our hair right? Wrong. Since my father was never the one to "doll" me up as a kid my hair was always straightened and styled as my mother had done her own hair. It wasn't until middle school that I discovered I actually had curly hair, but still I didn't have much help. Most days I just slathered gel into my hair and put it up in a pony tail high on my head. It wasn't until high school that I discovered the wonderul world of flat irons and blow dryers! Oh the awful things I did to my hair to make it as straight as I could, and I dreaded PE class and rainy days. I spent almost a good 10 years straightening my hair until I finally decided to give in and wear it curly because I had realized how ridiculous it was to spend so many hours on my hair! I've been wearing my hair curly for about a year now and it's definitely been a battle. I've spent a lot of hours on the internet trying to do my own research watching many many youtube videos, reading blogs, etc. I was a product junkie, buying things left and right thinking they did wonders on others hair, maybe they will do wonders on my own! It wasn't the case. It wasn't until I moved from Phoenix, AZ to Seattle, WA that I decided I had had enough, the amount of frizz I was dealing with because of rain or humidity was super frustrating. This book hasn't "solved" my problems, but it definitely gave me a lot of useful information towards helping care for my hair properly - basically every product I'd been using on my hair was a big no-no. If you can relate to any of my story, and are still struggling, I strongly recommend you purchase this book and give it a read. My hair isn't perfect yet, but I've only been at it for about a week or two, but I've noticed dramatic change in the shape of my curls. My hair is extremely dry and damaged from blow drying and dying so it will be a bit of a process.Bottom line...those that know me well, know I've struggled my whole life trying to tame this mane, and it's not been easy... oh the crazy things I've done, the many hours I've spent trying to make sure every strand was perfectly in place - and oh the many terrible haircuts from stylists having no idea how to manage my hair... the many tears shed. I've finally decided to embrace my crazy hair and start loving it how it should be loved. This book has a lot of useful information for curly hair. Please understand what works for some, may not work for everyone, but it's a learning experience! Don't expect this book to be a miracle worker and solve all your problems for you. It's meant as a guideline to help learn what works best for you, and remember it's going to take time a lot of practice, but I know once we get the hang of this it will all be worth it!

Loved, loved, loved this book.  Followed the recommendations and my frizzy hair has turned into beautiful curls.  I did buy the Curly Girl products  which really helped make a difference.  While I did notice a difference in the frizz factor immediately,  my curls were more wavy to start with but got curlier as my hair adjusted to the new regime.

I just took up the CG method and this book totally opened my eyes to how to take care of my curly hair. I had no idea my hair could look so incredibly healthy and the curls could be so defined. The book is great because all the models look like real/non photoshopped models, and they're all different ethnicities. There's even a whole chapter on "multi-curl-tural" hair!If you have curly hair and have always had trouble making it beautiful and healthy, I would HIGHLY recommend this book. You won't regret it.

LOVED this!  As a self-proclaimed beauty junkie (first step is admitting you have a problem, right?) that has accumulated WAY TOO MUCH beauty/hair products throughout the last 15ish years. But I don't know much at all concerning the "curly girl method" and wanted to look into it after my stylist told me it would make my hair much softer and stronger. Blogs I found were all contradictory, so i bought this book as all referred to it as the Bible of curly hair. It is detailed yet manageable, making it much more simple to understand than I had anticipated. Massey walks the reader through, step by step, how to eat care for curly hair. Her chapter on products did unfortunately lead me to spend more money on more products (last thing i needed!), but they have been game changers. Highly recommend!!

This book is an excellent start.  My daughter has very curly hair and it has always been fuzzy.  Don't think that following their directions will necessarily give you instant results--my daughter's hair needed time to heal I think.  It has steadily gotten more and more formed in the curls.  I followed up with looking at some posts by curly headed-girls who encouraged being flexible with your own hair and with the directions given here.  Sulfate-free is a must, and the major stores (Target, Wally World, etc.) carry a lot of great products now, and they don't cost an arm and leg.

PROS• Well written and well-edited, with a spirited and happy voice and cute puns throughout.• Clear instructions, with photos. You wouldn't think an adult would need this for hair washing and conditioning, but it's a totally different approach than what we learned from say, Prell commercials or Cosmo, and the author gets that, offering the necessary level of detail.• Admirably, doesn't push a specific brand of hair care. As Massey has founded two lines of such products, she easily could insist they are the only ones that work, so she scores credibility points for instead listing general ingredients to avoid, and others that are beneficial for curl cultivation.• This method really does work. My hair has never looked better. But...and this is a big one:DEAL-BREAKING CON• My skin has never looked worse....And yes, I keep my hair off my face at night by 'pineappling' it....And yes, I follow an impeccable skincare routine that includes exfoliating products.Until I read this book, I had my hair in a scrunchy bun all the time, as its texture was too weird to leave down. On the 'Curly Girl' method, its texture is sheaves of soft curls. But as they spill like rumpled silk over my shoulders, these highly conditioned curls also rest on the sides of my face. There, particulates of the un-rinsed conditioner and of the palms-full of gel saturating their cuticles transfer to my facial skin's clean, unassuming pores....And of that unholy union comes acne. I never had acne before starting Curly Girl, not even in my teens. A week and a half on this method and it's pimple city, they are rampant.It's as if we each have a set point for attractiveness, and the universe is saying: Sure, you can find a way to have nice hair, but doing so will ruin your skin, to keep you humble.

First thing I want to say: When you are reading ratings for products check the date of the reviews! They can be 10 years old and the product may have been changed five times. Book reviews don’t matter but if it is something you need up to date info., check the publication date.I have never been given anything including a discount for any of my reviews!I recommend this book even if you don’t have curly hair. This book is inexpensive and is full of information for anyone who cares about their hair.For example: No one should cut your hair wet. Especially curly hair. DO NOT ket someone use shampoo after they color or highlight your hair.High dollar salons sure seem to almost always to both.This book is wonderful. Learned so much about curly hair and hair products in general. There is so much in all the commercial products they use in marketing that actual make anyone’s hair worse, not better.My advice is that if it sounds like some chemical formula that you don’t know what it is, avoid that product.The following actually apply to anyone’s hair:Avoid products with silicone which is in just about every “shine” product because they are MADE to REPEL water.Avoid gels with any alcohol, silicone, parabens, and phthlates.“All Natural” is misleading. Something may be natural like hydrochloric acid but I don’t want it in my hair!Avoid shampoos with sulfates which you may already know.Look for products that contain shea butter, jojoba oil, olive oil, vegetable oils,  cetyl esters, aloe vera, propylene glycol, vegetable glycerin and sorbitol. You can find these single ingredients inexpensively on this site.My hair improved in one week after I quit using the stuff that was supposedly making it better. My hair is long and it had started to tangle so badly, I had to brush it before washing it, after conditioner and after I got out. The hair detangler allowed me to get it combed through when I used it but made it even worse in the long run.

Okay....so this book I’ve been really wanting to get for soooo long. But I have put it off until Hair Romance said it had good tips. It’s been one of those things that I’m like “Do I really need it!?” I could spend the money on products instead of a book and products would help me out much more than a $15 or $10 book would, right? Not really! Even though I watched years worth of videos from YouTube they will never equate to this book. Even though there are some things in the book that are a waste off time to read...(if you’re desperate like myself)....for example all of the curly girl testimonials but hay there’s much more... and you don’t have to read everything! Skim over it the first or second time like I did! Love the natural recipes in it (not a lot mind you) but very good tips. This book it where I found my grounding so I’d recommend getting it!The quality of the books actual material and design:Okay this part I’m not entirely impressed...the paper is the rubbery type that will leave a rippled finger print on it....and the paper has a plastic coating so it is easy to get a glare from the lighting. So that’s honestly quite annoying for me... I’m kind of picky when it comes to reading lol.  Hope this was helpful!

Changed my perspective on using gels. I am African so I was very skeptical as to applying gel to my hair...little did I knew that it would change my hair.This book has greatly simplified my washday routine and styling method. Be warned not much on each specific type of hair, about two pages, but still.Have yet to go over the CD-R.

I was so excited to get this book.  Unfortunately--while it was an easy and pleasant read--the methods didn't work for me.  I tried the Curly Girl methods for a good number of years, but ended up with the most unruly hair that I have ever had in my life.  It constantly tied itself into knots.  Eventually, I went for the big chop and started over, using my old routine again.  Nevertheless, I appreciate the idea of making peace with your own natural curls.  Long before this book, I have been sporting my natural curls.  I was just hoping for an easier routine.  This was not easier at all.  I found it tedious, as though my hair had special needs and was running my life.

This book is probably best for those who are still coming to terms with loving their natural hair, as a large portion of it is repeated stories about how your curls are awesome. If you've already come to acceptance of your not-straight hair, this book may get real old, real fast. There are a ton of personal testimonials, 'cutesy' repeated slang terms like "hair fryer" (instead of hair dryer), and so on, and it does not let up over the course of the book.I wish instead there had been more about modifications beyond the One True Way outlined in the book:- She sniffs at the thought that you might not be able to spend the needed time on your hair in the morning, but what if your hair is very thick and takes forever to air dry? Some discussion of night-before washing and hair prep methods would have been useful; using a diffuser or your car's heater may work for some people but isn't always feasible.- The sole mention of dandruff is essentially 'see a dermatologist' - well yes, but what about suggestions to try to mitigate the curl-busting effects of what might be necessary (and hopefully temporary) use of harsh shampoos or treatments?- The hair spritz for scalp "cleaning" between washing says you should use lavender, but it can be irritating to skin (especially in sunlight) and doesn't really seem to have any true cleansing effects. Another oil option would have been nice.I do give her credit for not turning the book into one big ad for her hair products line (DevaCurl), as well as for providing some DIY product instructions if you're into that.I've seen complaints that the videos don't work on Kindle, but they do work in the Kindle for iPad app, for those interested.

I have started the CGM and enjoyed most of the content outlined in the book. I have a few disagreements but will use much of what I learned in my hair journey. As with any book, how-to-guide I take it with a grain of salt. I am not a die-hard and will not “obey” every rule outlined in this book but most was very good solid advice for caring and cultivating curls/waves in one’s hair. I am a 2b wavy girl. I use sulfate free shampoo periodically, I brush my hair in the shower, and I sleep on a regular cotton pillowcase with my hair free...these are not really recommended by true CGM standards, but it works for me and my lifestyle. Still I am grateful for Lorraine Massey and her passion to help curly and wavy girls realize that the hair God blessed them with is actually what looks best on them and to be brave enough to let their natural beauty shine out for all to see :)

Having wavy hair and a daughter with really curly hair, I had to get this book. I'm so glad I did. Some of the book is really cheesy, like using "hair" sayings to make a point like "self mane-tenance" or "It's all about Hue!" or another, "The down and dirty root-ine".  Gag. I am not a fan of playing on words. She did it throughout the entire book. Drove me nuts after awhile. Also, I got this book for my daughter and the quiz at the beginning had some questions that didn't really apply to a pre-teen, like "Do you live in fear of humidity, sweating, spontaneous sex, a shower with your lover..."  Yeah, she doesn't need to read that. Not only that, the author assumes that us girls with curly or wavy hair, hate our hair. I don't hate my hair. She also suggests throwing away your straightener. What? No. What if I want a different look? Straight haired girls curl their hair so what is wrong with me straightening mine? Just silly.I do like the book though because it had a lot of tips for making my hair look better. I gave up shampoo and boy did that make a difference! I would have never known. I also like her ideas for making my hair more curly/wavy. I didn't even use the DVD because honestly, the book did a great job of describing how to make my hair work for me. I recommend this book to any person who has curly or wavy hair. It really helped me and I do love my hair a little more, even if I think the author is a corn ball.

While I realize this book was primarily written to sell the Deva haircare products (which are fabulous), there's a lot of good styling tips in this book.  In the past, one of the problems of being a curly head is the lack of good styling products, but also a lack of good technique.  I was lucky and got it on sale for $1.99 kindle price, so I certainly got my money's worth.  For example, I never thought to use clips to give volume to the top of my hair at the crown.  The videos were helpful what with Picture.ThousandWords and all.  So I highly recommend this for the styling techniques, especially for keeping the curls defined and losing the frizz.The book is liberally sprinkled with curly hair confessionals where various women write of their apparent trauma of having curly hair.  As someone who never had an issue with her curly hair (because I realized early on a lot of women spend a much time and small fortune trying to achieve what I was just lucky enough to be born with!) I didn't find these particularly enlightening.  But I suppose if one has fought against their hair, or had been teased about it, these might be of some comfort to know you're not alone.  Acceptance is a good thing!It loses a star because the book actually contains a section regarding horoscopes and your hair.  Seriously!  But I suppose if someone is the kind of person who both knows their astrological sign (but probably not their blood type) and believes that the position of planets, stars and constellations in the sky have some meaning to your hair, this might be helpful to them.  For me it was laughable waste of space.

Recently decided to commit to my curly hair.  This book doesn't really help all that much.  I found it difficult to determine my curl type from this (and author states it's likely you have more than one type) so also difficult to know which protocol to follow.  What I struggle with the most is knowing how much of product to use and which products are best for my curly hair.  I've been experimenting with both protocols and products.  So far, I've eliminated a lot through trial and error bit still on the hunt for what works best.  Watching YouTube videos has been much more helpful than this book.

This book has made such a difference as I’ve let go of keeping my hair straight. I only wish I found it sooner. If you’re wondering how to work with your natural hair texture instead of trying to beat it into submission, start here.When you’re done with this book and you’re still trying to find the right products, application and technique to bring out your best curls, buy Scott Musgrave’s online class The MAP Method. Yes, they’re are wonderful and free online resources but the information can be conflicting, daunting, and time consuming to sort through. Scott cuts to the chase and helps you understand your hair now. So, for about $115 (the cost of this book plus Scott’s class) and a month of your time while you study and practice, you can have beautiful, healthy hair you never dreamed you could have. That’s cheap folks. Us gals spend more than that on a single trip to the salon for a cut and color.

I live in Colorado and have a lot of problems with my hair the last few years. It's so dry here, and with the high altitude, it's almost impossible to keep my wavy/curly hair hydrated, un-frizzed, and looking good. A couple of years ago I switched to using Wen as my wash/conditioner, and used some of the other Wen products to help with frizz and hydration. For awhile the products worked really well for me, but the last year, I've had less than stellar results. Also, the products keep going up in price, and I felt like I was spending a fortune just to keep my hair in okay shape.I am so glad I stumbled on this book! It has changed my curly hair life, saved me a ton of money, and my hair hasn't looked this good in I don't know how long. I followed the techniques outlined in the handbook, and with just a little experimenting with amounts of conditioner and gel, my hair is looking fantastic, feels hydrated, isn't a frizzy mess, and feels good to the touch. I'm using a sulfate-free shampoo and botanical conditioner by Alba, about $10 each at my local health food store, a higher end gel, and a little bit of leave-in conditioner/styling elixir by 2Chic. None of the products are super expensive as compared to what I was using before, and I think the technique and products work well together. I shampoo as per the instructions, then condition. It took a few washes to get the amount of conditioner and how much I was rinsing out right, but it was worth the experimentation. I scrunch a couple of times after the shower, add my gel, scrunch once, then add my elixir and scrunch a final time. The only thing with this process is that it takes my hair awhile to dry.I love the homemade recipes in the book, and the tips for styling. Again, affordable and easy to make recipes, and simple styling tips. This is the best purchase I've made for my hair in a very long time. Get the book, follow the instructions for your curl type, experiment for a few washes, and after 2-3 weeks, you'll be surprised at how much difference there is. I could see a little improvement after one wash, but after refining my process and what I'm using on my hair, there's an enormous difference.

This is an excellent starting point if you are trying to embrace your waves and curls and don't know where to begin. I have naturally thick, wavy hair that I have been flat ironing daily for years now and I am over it. It takes me hours! A friend recommended this book to me and I love it. Lots of pictures with step by step instructions, which is exactly what I need. Mine even came with a DVD and I plan to watch it. Is this book totally comprehensive? No. I don't think that's even possible! But it Is definitely something I will be referencing as I learn and then will pass on eventually. If you are just starting, start here!

This is a very informative, encouraging book for those who have decided to embrace their beautiful God-given  curly hair. It's not easy! For those of us who have been made fun of (Brillo pad!), had our hair cut short by our parents, and spent hours straightening out hair only to walk outside and instantly lose the style to frizz and poof, it requires a complete change in the way we think about our hair. But when a stranger stops you and says, "I just have to tell you - your hair is awesome!" Well, it's all worth it. (No one ever told me that in all the years I spent blow drying and trying to control my hair.) Pretty soon you are looking in the mirror and realizing your hair IS awesome! So glad I found this book and embraced my curls.

Game chager. I've been using her product line Deva Curl but doing it my own way until I got this book. Amazing results. I have gotten so many more compliments for my curly hair. Even my stylist asked me what I was doing. I now tell every curly girl and every closet curly girl (aka straightens her hair every day and prays it doesn't rain) about this book. I love my curly hair and this just makes it amazing and non-crunchy. It's a lot to get used to at first but it's worth it. It takes a long time for my hair to dry after washing but on the non-washing days hair care is a breeze and looks even better than the washing days! The books is very curl-centric and anti straightening your hair ever-but it's easy to get past that. Love that she explains the why behind what you should and shouldn't do. I accidentally used a prior product (silk drops) on a non-washing day and looked at the ingredients after I used it; there was a huge difference. Who knew the products I was using to tame my hair were a huge part of the problem.

All the info I desperately needed and wonderfully reassuring to find out I am not alone in my years of misery at the hands of stylists.  My hair has been in a very very bad way for too long and nothing seemed to be working.  Two weeks in and maybe not the most perfect routine yet but my curls are starting to amaze me.  Instead of a tangle of dry sad frizz there are these defined curls.  My only wish is that there was an index, to help me get back to specific how to parts easier.  I wish I would have found this book years ago.  Somethings I already knew but so much I did not.  Highly recommended!!

This book is a great help to people who have curly hair and don't know what to do with it. Unlike most of the people who give testimonies in the book, I did not have curly hair my whole life. I ended up with curly hair after losing all of my hair from chemotherapy treatments. When my hair finally grew back in, it came in a completely different color and in tight corkscrew curls! I read the Curly Girl handbook, followed the instructions and found that my hair definitely looked better. I confess that I didn't always understand how to do the various techniques just by reading and looking at the pictures, so I searched for a nearby salon that might be able to teach the techniques hands-on. The salon I found has two stylists who actually went to New York and were trained by Lorraine Massey. I came away from my appointment with a clear understanding of how to care for my hair - how much conditioner and gel to use, how to use clips to lift and accentuate my curls, how to dry my hair with a diffuser, how to rejuvenate my curls on the second and third days, etc.  And my hair has looked great ever since!

This book is for woman who have yet to proficiently take care of their curls. You must have literally little to no knowledge at all of how to maintain, brush, wash, and cut your hair. Much of this handbook is composed of common sense, and the rest lacking thereof. It's quite a let down since it came highly recommended... but again, if you are confident in your current abilities, don't fool yourself and think you'll learn anything new.

I picked up this book because I desperately need to know how to care for my curls. The book is extremely informative on how to identify what kind of curls you have and how to treat and maintain your curls.What I enjoyed most about the book is, even though the author is the creator of the DEVA CURL hair line products, she didn't use this book to promote it. Instead she gave a list of ingredients in hair products to look for and look out for, so you can make your own decisions on what to purchase. She just truly wants you to love your curls!So I just had my first cut from a professional curl stylist, and with the help of this book I plan on going through a curl hair journey! Buy the book, and love your curls.Side note: I purchased the kindle version and enjoyed watching the videos on my kindle app on using my iPad.

This is a must have for anyone who wants to control curly hair. I got this book, and I found a devacurl trained stylist, and my hair never looked better. It has descriptions for all sorts of different curl types, and recommended ways to style. Not much of an exaggeration to say it changed both my and my mother's lives

I have fine, curly hair and have never been proud of my curls...they always felt very lifeless and were hard to take care of (thin and curly hair is not exactly an ideal combination). After having used sulfate laden shampoos and paraben ladedn conditioners until the beginning of this summer, I bought this book at the recommendation of a friend of mine, and out of curiosity. The homemade shampoos and conditioners I was using while effective at detangling, were making my hair limp, oily, and lifeless. I started reading The Curly Girl Handbook and figured out what curls I have (Botticelli) and how to care for them and was very excited. I had no idea curly hair DID have to be treated differently than straight hair.  I read about the DevaCurl products and actually just bought the No Poo and One Conditioner today, and they are a literal miracle; I had oily, lifeless, gross hair and LITERALLY while rinsing the No Poo from my head, my hair changed 100%. It was soft, strong, not weighed down, bouncy, light, etc. AMAZING. The conditioner is equally amazing as it provides SO MUCH nourishment and detangle in such a small amount.Anyway, back to the book. The book is essential for anyone with curly or wavy hair. Lorraine really does understand how unique curly hair is and her mantra is for everyone to embrace their curls, not try to conform to the current idea and standard of beauty (straight hair) and to be proud to have stand out curls. The tips are easy to understand (I especially love the homemade stuff she came up with, like the Lavender Spray) and everything is super easy to do, even down to how exactly you should wash your hair. I HIGHLY HIGHLY recommend this....it's seriously going to change your life, because it did mine....and I'm a proud Curly Girl now!

Loved this book! Had LOTS of great information on curly hair.I’ve had somewhat curly hair all my life. I grew up in the 70’s when straight hair was “in” so I fought my hair all my life.Due to health issues I lost a lot of hair but since it’s grown back, it’s SUPER curly! I decided to quit fighting and embrace it. The curly hair struggle is real if you’re “doing it wrong”! That’s why I bought this book to learn how finally to live with curly hair!  Good book! Even bought an extra one for a gift - she loved it too!

This book is literally LIFE CHANGING.  I have despised my curls since I was a little girl.  But now that I have a curly-headed daughter of my own, I've been trying to teach her to love her hair for years.  Insisting that she loves her curls while frying mine with a flat iron every day seemed hypocritical.I'd been trying to go back to curly for weeks with pretty awful/stringy results so I turned to Google for help.  It turns out that I just needed to understand what my hair really needs.I am still in the funky phase between flat iron/keratin treatments but so far it is amazing.  I can't wait to see how my curls end up once all the damage has been repaired.

I wish this book had been around when I was growing up, it would have made life with my hair a lot easier! I've only been shampoo free for a little over a week but already a co-worker has noticed a difference. More important, it drove home something my 4 year old granddaughter ( a curly girl born of 2 straight hair parents ) said to me at the end of a day spent together. I had straightened my hair that day - something I usually did only once a week as I have been coming to terms with my hair for a couple of years now and figured this was about as good as it was going to get. From the back seat she asked me when my hair was going to look like hers again and I asked her why, don't you like it like this? She said no, I like it better when it's like mine. Out of the mouths of babes! Luckily my daughter is very geared towards the more natural the better and has been shampoo free for over a month and follows the same path with my granddaughter. Thanks to this " how to " book, I think I can finally become more comfortable in my own curls and be a better curly hair role model for my granddaughter.

If you have natural curly hair, this is a must read. If your daughter has natural curly hair and you do not, PLEASE get this book for your child's sake! Growing up with a straight-haired mom, my hair really suffered at the hands of brushes and the wrong hair products. Bless my mom, she tried her best, but my hair was always frizzy and massive as a kid. After reading this book and buying the DevaCurl products, my hair has never looked better; my daughter's looks amazing as well with it. The volume for the first time ever is manageable and the curls are each defined and not crispy and crunchy anymore. I've tried every product for curly hair available and still can't believe that all it takes is the deva shampoo, conditioner, and light gel. But the book is a must so you know how to properly wash and dry your hair. Trust me, download the book now!

1) I can appreciate the information in this book.  I do think that the CG Methods are helpful for anyone starting their curly hair journey.  However, most of this information is available online for free.  There was no new information that I haven't already read/seen before.  I would save my money and research.2) I purchased the digital copy of this book.  The book was intended to include videos explaining some of her methods.  The links didn't work.  The format was altogether messy and poorly designed.  Not at all what I would expect from a $9 kindle book.Overall- not worth the investment.

I ordered Curly Girl many years ago and have borrowed it to one too many friends over the years. I still tell anyone who asks about how I take care of my curly hair about this book. Anytime someone new cuts my hair they comment on how healthy it is (which is not common for curly hair). I recently decided that I needed another copy since my first was lost. I also have have a mini curly girl and am happy to provide her with years less of grief over curly hair than I had. This book is SUCH a wonderful tool for anyone with curly hair to have so they can learn how to take care of it properly! If you or your girl has curly hair this book is for you! It is a lifesaver!! It discusses many types of curly hair from a little wave to course, kinky hair. Many home recipes to have the healthiest curly hair possible are included. Nothing has ever helped me take care of and be happy with my curly hair as this book!!

Quitting my hairstylist who rips through my hair with a paddle brush before coloring my hair and tends to cut too much off. Last time my scalp itched during the coloring process and my hair was so dry none of the multitudes of hair products I had could fix it.  I purchased a filter for my shower head and a deep conditioner which helped. But today after reading this book and all the lables on my hair products I decided to give it a try. I made my own lavender mist using fresh lavender from the garden using a distilling process to extract the oil mixed it with water and vegetable glycerin which I just happened to have and put it in a spray bottle to use as a curl refresher. The videos in the book are great...and my hair looks and feels amazing the cut even looks better..the info in this book was well worth the price of the book...I'm so inspired and will find a Deva curl specialist in my area for sure!

I'm 63 yo and have always had a little wave in the back of my hair, but about 5 years ago I started developing ringlets on  my nape hair.  Now I have full blown curly hair (ringlets everywhere) and I didn't  know what to do with it.  This book has really helped me get my hair under control, my curls are defined and look great and they look even better on day 2 :)  I've only been on the program for 2 weeks so I'm looking forward to seeing the progression.  I'm also excited I found a stylist that has taken Devacurl classes.

This review is about how this book has effected me and also about some of the products made by the same people/company. I think that there are plenty of specifics about what the book contains, so this is my personal response. If you have had curls all you life this might not apply to you, but if you find yourself suddenly curly compliments of chemo, read on.To start with, let me explain that I really always wanted curly hair, and never had it naturally. I was the perm queen in the 80's (yes I am dating myself).  When I was diagnosed with cancer I had hair that was past my bra strap, and cut with the Presage method (a cut that adds curl). Anyway, after Chemo and Radiation when my hair started coming back curly, I was thrilled. Finally I would have those long beautiful curly locks I had spent so much time and money pursuing.  But wait, where were the beautiful locks? First I looked like my grandma (short frizzy helmet of hair) and then instead of growing longer, my hair grew out.... Straight out.  I was thinking a job at the local circus would be my best option.  One day after crying for about an hour (literally) I decided to quit feeling sorry for myself and do something about it. So I went to Amazon, and lo and behold I found this book.When my hair started growing out, it was a train wreck. After applying the information from the book, about 70% of the time people now ask me who does my hair or what I do to it (seriously-not making this up). I went from frizz to beautiful fat curls. If you are dealing with Chemo Curl, I highly recommend this book and the related products. Although there is a specific chapter about Chemo Curl, don't just read it, read the whole book (the Chemo chapter was somewhat disappointing to me).Obviously I am not going to tell you everything that this book says. If you are dealing with the same things that I was, I would suggest that the first thing that you do (while you are waiting for this book to arrive) is go out and get a microfiber towel. Stop using your normal towel to dry your hair!! I went ahead and bought the Deva Curl No Poo Deva Curl No Poo 32oz,Zero Lather Conditioning Cleanser,  Deva Curl Low Poo DEVA by Deva Concepts CURL LOW POO ALL HAIR TYPES 32 OZ and Deva Curl conditioner Deva Curl Ultra Creamy  Daily Conditioner, One Condition, 32-Ounces. Although they all have pro's and cons, for a beginner like me they all were worth it. (I am going to try and do reviews on those when I get the time).To sum it up, after Chemo rather than buying a flat iron or a bunch of handkerchiefs, buy this book. It really helped me take a bad situation and turn it around. You don't realize how much you identify with your hair until you look in the mirror and hate what you see. Trust me, you have been thru enough already. Take those curls and own them. They are beautiful, maybe different, but definitely beautiful! By the way, Congratulation on getting those Chemo Curls, it means you are still here baby, still fighting!! You go with your beautiful self!!!

Love this book!  I have fought the curly-hair curse for years... the fluff, the frizz, the frowns in the morning.  But, this book has answers to many of those problems.  I've made some changes in my hair regime over the last week and now my hair is less frizzy (almost completely gone), way softer and less dry, and much more manageable.  The "homemade recipes" are easy to create and really do work!  The only thing that I wish was that this book named products to use, rather than just ingredients to avoid.  I have had to do some of my own research to find products and locate places to buy them.  However, I think that I have begun a new and happier chapter in my curly-haired life, thanks to the Curly Girl Handbook!!!

I've heard/read a lot about the Curly Girl Method through online blogs, YouTube, etc. My mom has naturally curly hair that she is still trying to learn how to tame and manage. She is also in her 60's so the online format and resources of blogs and YouTube aren't the most practical methods of learning for her. I was happy when I saw this came in book form. I purchased this Curly Girl Method book as a gift for my mom and her hair has never looked better!

Pretty good read.  I have "slightly" wavy hair and although switching to some of the recommended products may enhance that slight wavy, the tips on scrunching etc don't seem to work for me.  It is a lot of extra work to try to encourage my hair to curl.  I'll keep trying for a while.  I was already using sulfate free shampoos and conditioners so maybe my fine hair just won't take a curl very well.

I am a Devacurl convert as of about 4 months ago.  I have very delicate cherub curls, and my hair has been breaking off like it's going out of style for the past many years.  I have been brushing, combing, blow drying and flat ironing my hair to death.  By fighting my natural texture, I was killing my hair.  I decided to try something new, because I have spent thousands of dollars following my hair dresser's suggestions, and all of those suggestions have not helped me successfully grow my hair out.  I have very fine hair but lots of it, and it tends to break once it gets to my chin.  After doing EXTENSIVE research, including reading several clinical research papers, I concluded that sulfates were the reason for my hair breakage.  It isn't that sulfates are bad themselves, but its the fact that they strip my hair of the natural oils that protect each strand and keep them hydrated.  By stripping the hair of moisture, frying it and brushing it, my hair was brittle and totally destroyed by the time it reached my chin.  Washing hair with sulfates remove oil and more protein from the hair than using non-sulfate shampoos.  When I was doing all this on a daily basis, my hair was half broken off by the time it reached my shoulders.  This made growing my hair out nearly impossible.I started using the Devacurl Lowpoo/One condition, and after about a month, I moved on to use the Devaurl NoPoo and One Condition every other day.  I have completely stopped brushing my hair. I follow the curly girl method almost perfectly, and my hair has never looked better.  It's hydrated and it looks full and thick.  My hair is finally happy, and I now get compliments on it often.  My hair routine only takes 2 minutes, as apposed to 45 minutes that I used to spend killing my hair with various torture devices (blow dryer and flat iron).Here is my routine that I swear by:I get in the shower and wet my hair with warm water, apply nopoo to my fingertips and then massage it into my scalp for an entire minute.  I do not bring it through the ends of my hair.  I don't touch the ends of my hair when I am cleansing my scalp.  I then rinse my hair under the water of the shower for about 30 seconds.  Then I apply the One Condition from the roots to the tips of my hair, and I use a Mason Pearson wide tooth comb to distribute the conditioner and detangle my hair while in the shower.  I also use the comb to make a straight part in my hair (if I don't do this, my hair is kind of a mess at the top).  I wash out the conditioner and I gently cup my hair with a microfiber towel once I get out of the shower.  I use the microfiber towel to dry my hair with the gentle up motions; it's not really scrunching, it's more like scrunching with an open hand.  I then put a little bit of Devacurl Foam on the roots, and a tiny bit of Devacurl Angel on the tips.  I let my hair air dry and I don't touch it until it's totally dry.  The products help the hair stick together while it's drying, so it maintains the curl pattern without frizz.  When my hair is totally dry, I then gently shake the hair at the roots, and fluff up the ends by going around my head with open palmed "scrunches."  I never rake through my hair from roots to tips with my fingers when it's dry as this leads to a fluffy/frizzy mess.The Devacurl products also don't have silicones that aren't water soluble, so you don't have to use harsh cleansers to avoid product buildup.  This is a VERY important piece of information.  If you are going the no sulfate route, make sure that you are using products that have ingredients that are water soluble.  If not, you will have a massive buildup of products in your hair.  I was using a silicone mousse, and it made my hair look about three shades darker.  I thought the color change was because of my natural oils, but after I used a clarifying cleanser, the silicones washed out and my hair went back to it's normal texture and color.  Silicones are great for my hair, but I can't easily wash them out of my hair without using drying shampoos, so I now avoid them.It takes awhile for curly hair to get used to not being abused, so you should expect a period of chaos on your head for a bit, but once that period is over, you will be so happy you did this.  I am never going back to regular shampoos, and I don't plan to brush my hair ever again (even though I truly love my Mason Pearson brush, I will have to find another use for it).UPDATE: Since I started (several months ago) applying the curly girl method to my hair, I have not found ONE broken hair anywhere; yes, I actually check when I find them to see if the root is attached.  I used to find broken off ends everywhere but those days are over :)

Fast shipping, book in Brand New condition.  Absolutely love the Curly Girl method!  It has made a HUGE difference in my and my daughter's hair.  Even my husband has noticed and has been very complimentary.  Well worth the read and change in our routine, and overall it takes less time.  Read the book, follow her advice, and enjoy your amazing new life of gorgeous curly hair.

I had no clue how to maintain and style my curly hair. I have type 2a curly and it's always been so frizzy! I've been pulling it back for years now because I just didn't like the way it looked. After reading the book, I found out that I've been using the wrong type of shampoo/conditioner/styling products. I went and purchased sulfate/silicone/paraben free products and HOLY COW. In the  description of the item it mentions that the book comes with DVD Which was my main reason for purchase but unfortunately it does NOT come with the DVD and that’s why I’m returning the book.

This book has been revised and updated with considerably more information and is a great read.  It's a lot of fun especially for those with curly hair with little/no idea how to take full advantage of that texture.The book begins with the Author's own bio and how she fought, then reconciled, then rejoiced in her own curls, starting the Devachon salon, which specializes in curly haired clients.  She then introduces the many different kinds of curls and how to determine which type of curl you have. While I found this interesting, I wasn't personally able to determine my own curl type, because some of the criteria overlap onto more than one curl type. However, the information is still helpful and entertaining.  Other chapters deal with hair styles for curly hair, general care and coloring of curly hair.  The updated book also includes a CD ROM disc which instructs how to cut one's own hair. These instructions are only applicable to someone with very long curly hair which can be pulled to the front of the face, those of us with shorter hair aren't able to see our hair to clip ends evenly. Frankly I would not recommend this to anyone since IMO success with curly hair is 95% all about the cut, which should be left to the care of a stylist experienced in cutting curly hair (and ladies, regardless of what they say, not all stylists can cut curly hair successfully )In summary, this is a fun and educational book which should leave curly girls far more knowledgeable about their curls, the care and holding their head up with pride.

This book helped me so much with my hair. If you have wavy, curly, frizzy or unruly hair get this book! My hair is thick and wavy, it’s always been a frizzy horrible mess that I flat ironed almost daily for 20 years. I’ve done the curly girl method for 2 months and my hair is transformed into healthy shiny extra wavy no frizzy hair. For the first time in my life I can honestly say I like my hair.

I think the information in this book is probably helpful to some, not so helpful for others. It may have to do with age, hair type, style of hairdo you like, etc.. I'm 61 with gray hair that's shoulder length, thick and curly..I can't really say which kind of curls I have, because reading through the description of the different kinds, I couldn't really find one that fit my hair..However,  I've been using sulfate free shampoos for years and have always used lots of conditioners (also sulfate free)... My hair has become more dry with age, especially since letting it go naturally gray.. I can only wash it now a couple of times a week or it is a dried out mess.. However, using the method described in this book (only shampooing your scalp then allowing the shampoo to run down the rest while rinsing) and then using a lot of conditioner that you rinse by gently throwing water at your head just didn't work well for me. The idea is to leave conditioner in to moisturize the hair.. It made my head itch!After cleansing, you are to gently squeeze out moisture with a tshirt or special towel, squeezing the curls upwards, never drying your hair like you normally do with a towel (trying to get as much water out as possible..big no no).. You are also not suppose to comb or bursh your hair.. After using the tshirt or special towel to squeeze out water, you use a handful of gel (with no alchohal and a list of other chemicals.. Very hard to find by the way..), you apply it to hair and then squeeze the hair upwards, to lock in the curls.. You then use clips to lift parts of your hair on the top of your head if need be and leave it alone to dry.. You can use a defuser on the ends, but it's not really recommended, but rather, turn up the heater in your car on the way to work.Okay, at 61, I don't want those tight, crispy curls created by this method.. I also have hot flashes and would not enjoy turning up the heater in my car to dry my curls (lol)... I did try this method and found that even using a defuser to remove a little of the moisture, after washing my hair in the morning, it was still damp at the roots when I went to bed that evening...I keep my hair longer because I pull it up in a curly ponytail or messy bun 99% of the time.. I dry my bangs with a round brush and my hair dryer, but using this method, one is to let the bangs dry naturally.. Not a good look for me... My bangs do curl on humid days and I like them that way, but just allowing them to dry curly after shampooing/conditioning, well, they look goofy..If I had known about this method when I was a young woman, I may have liked it, although, I've never been one to like that crispy curl look. I like my hair to be soft.. Using this method, you aren't suppose to touch your curls, just leave them alone.. If need be, you can gently use your fingers to seperate the curls, whatever... I did try this method twice, so for one week I had these crispy like curls.. I found it very difficult to deal with them on a daily basis.. My curly pony tail is full of bouncy curls, but using this method, they were just really flat, crispy curls.. I like my bouncy curls better..Like I said, it probably has a lot to do with age.. The book is interesting, but honestly, I think I just found out I know more about my curls than I thought I did... I've been taking care of them pretty darn good all of my life.. I tried a chemical straightner once in my life, realized how damaging it was and didn't do that again. I've blown dried my hair straight on occassions (in the winter) and used a flat iron to straighten it, and enjoyed that look occassionally, and honestly, can't see where it's harmed my hair at all (maybe if I did this daily it would, but I never have)... To be honest, it's a lot easier to just let my hair do what it wants to do, which is curl, so for the most part, I really do enjoy having hair that I can wash, dry my bangs and just let the rest of it dry curly without having to mess with it... Like so many others, I wanted straight hair when I was young. I used to save orange juice cans to roll my hair with.. I actually slept with a headfull of juice cans in order to have straight hair.. Now my sisters, who have straight hair, tell me I'm the lucky one...their hair just gets limp and looses it's shape when it's humid.. Mine just gets curlier. I've learned to love my curls, but I didn't need this book to get there..

I really like this book. I got some very good advice, some I'm sure I could've found on the internet, but I like to re-read books. I had always rinsed my conditioner because I thought it would weigh my hair down if I left it in. Now, I just splash water on the top of my head, and squeeze the excess out with a t-shirt, add a leave in and a serum, and plop.  After reading the book, I have switched to a no sulfate shampoo and a no "cones" conditioner. I am seeing a difference in my hair and liking it. I have followed a lot of the advice for my curly/wavy hair which has always had a mind of its own, lol. As I've gotten older, I have just learned to enjoy my hair and let it be itself. My hair is not as dry and frizzy, I wish it was even less frizzy, but I am confident that the more I keep treating my hair like this, the better it will be. Very enjoyable book.

I have owned the orginal "Curly Girl" handbook for nine years, but it has come apart at the seams, so I bought this updated version. This is a much-improved 'part 2' to the original book. Here, we get more advice and improved methods of taking care of curls and waves. It includes updates with a few of the women from the original book as well as the stories of new women and even a couple of men. There's are also new chapters about the dangers of thermal reconditioning and women who came out of chemotherapy with curly hair growing in. It even includes a DVD that demonstrates how to take care of curls. My one minor complaint about this book is that while there are more options as to what kind of curls exist, I still do not fall into any one catagory. I would say that I am a Corkscrew curly, but my hair doesn't have its 'symptoms' (I can't use things like hot oil or cream gel because it sits on my hair and makes it stringy). Then there's the new Corkicelli curl, whose symptoms I seem to have, but my hair doesn't look anything like. I just follow the procedure for Botticelli hair, even though it is probably not my hair type. Also, I have to admit that I am intimidated by the idea of having to cut my own hair because of the ignorance of most salons; every salon I've ever gone to brushes my hair, shampoos it and cuts it wet (the wrong way). Still, I know that the authors are right because of how great my hair looks now that I know what to do with it. I gave the original book four stars; I'll give this one a perfect five.

The book was filled with a lot of information of which I was not aware.  However, this is a real commitment for a lifetime if you choose to keep your curls.  Also the products are expensive.  I would like to have seen some diy recipes for products or organic choices.  I have thin hair and would like to see a chapter on how to make my hair look thicker and still be healthy.

Or your child’s. I got this for my niece and her mom, as my side of the family is biracial and my sister-in-law is caucasion. My curl is different from niece, but no less a nightmare to maintain. This book goes through the various “types” of curls, how to wash and maintain, how to detangle, how to cut and style - just everything. Also, a lot of useful information about product ingredients that can help or harm curls. My hairdresser recommended this book to me 15 years ago, and after finally buying it now, I really wish I had listened sooner.

She has and knows how to work with curly hair.  My hair is thick and coarse with S curls and now has no little to no frizz.  AND...I found a stylist, as she recommends to do,  that knows how to cut curly hair...what a difference!  I now love my curly hair!!! Oh...and I am not using a comb.  Just took a little convincing.  :)  Her products are amazing.  That is all my new stylist uses which is also a plus.  She gave me a few pointers on the no comb thing.  I am so delighted and get compliments on my hair daily.  I even quit coloring it.  Absolutely amazed at the difference.  I share the book with all my curly haired friends.Previous review.....I like her book but, I don't think I can go without using a comb.  I tried it a first but my hair is very thick, wavy, s'wavy and it gets tangled throughout a day.  I am still working with her products.  This regimen requires a new paradigm shift for me.  I will update in a few months as it is a work in progess.

I have always had hair that tended to get REALLY BIG.  It would start out fine after I got out of the shower and as the day progressed- my hair got more and more volume.  Blow-drying would give me hair that the big hair bands would have killed for.  My hair seriously missed its decade.  When I saw this book- I thought I would give it a try.  I was hopeful, but skeptical that it could do something to help me.  I still haven't figured out just which kind of curl my hair is- so I'm playing around with different ways of washing it.  But the difference has been HUGE.  My hair is much curlier than I every thought.  And it's not trying to soak up every bit of humidity in the air.  I can definitely go out and not worry that my hair is going to go wild on me.  My husband loves that I'm now wearing my hair down instead of always clipped up.  Was this a life changing book for me?  Probably not- but I am much happier with my hair now.  I highly encourage you to try it out!

I starting reading this book about a week ago and now I'm in love with my curls.  I've never been one to straighten my hair or battle against my curls. But I still suffered with dry frizzy hair. Most days I would wear my hair tied back, if I did wear it down it would look nice for an hour or 2 and then frizz.My whole family have curly hair and I 'thought' I understood it. I just didn't feel I had the time or money to look after it right - I was wrong!!It's super easy to do. You can use cheap grocery store brands (I use Tresemme Naturals Conditioner) - just remember to read the ingredients!  It takes me about 5 mins to wash/style my shoulder length hair now. And my hair has never looked better - and it's only been a week!This book also has a section on kids hair. I now know how to look after my daughter's curly hair, so no more tears and tantrums in the mornings! Bliss!I HIGHLY recommend this book to anyone with curly or wavy hair.

I was hoping for more instruction. I had already figured out you can’t brush curly hair. But only getting out knots when you condition, what about when you shampoo?! Would be good for those that feel alone as it has a lot of personal sad stories (they didn’t make me feel better or help me have nicer curls).

Better than any product I could have bought. This information is worth gold. It's been a 3 month journey so far but my curls and I are rejoicing...boy had I missed them but baby they're bouncing back!

Yes love, love,... its my go to book. when i'm stuck... and don't know what to do with my hairit gives me encouragement that you can do things to help your beast on top of your head hahalove the homemade recipes in the back.. wish it had a lot more.. and love the hair styles in the back also wish it had more.On the other side, I wish it had more to talk about Botticelli type curls, and it had more talk about ingredients that are both good and bad to use..wish I knew what to do if you wanted to blend their deva curl products with other ones because the deva curl don't always work with other products I'd assume and to use all deva curl products together is just too expensive for me.

A must have book to tell you how to handle your curls, if you have curly hair.  My daughter has a combination of Chinese & Black hair, which it's not nappy or kinky, but it is very curly.  I happen to have wavy Chinese hair, instead of straight.  She has several different curl types and sometimes her hair is a challenge to manage, but this book shows her how to do it.  Plus, I take her to a salon once every 6 months and that combined with this book, which that salon does stuff that this book talks about, is great for my daughter.  Wish I had known about doing this when she was younger.  It would have saved me a lot of pain and heartache, and frustration.

As a Curly Girl myself I wanted to read this to see what all the fuss is about.  This book is full of information in an informal chatty format.  It validated a lot of what I was already doing with my hair and I've incorporated many of the suggestions from the book.  My wavy/curly hair is now healthier looking, softer, and frizz-free.  I'm glad I read it.

I do the curly girl method already and my friend seemed interested in it so I got her the book on how to care  for Hair! It’s an awesome guide to caring for all types of hair and different recipes and things to avoid.

I bought this looking for the Holy Grail in hair care. Pretty darn close. The author has seriously curly hair and chronicles her own struggles to make peace with her hair. I implemented a number of the recommendations - use the hair clips while drying my hair every day, sought out her hair products Deva Curl shampoo, conditioner, texture wave and gel which all work as described.
